description:
Melanerpes formicivorus, commonly known as the Acorn Woodpecker, is a species of bird found in western North America. It belongs to the family Picidae, which includes woodpeckers, sapsuckers, and flickers.

The Acorn Woodpecker is a medium-sized bird, typically measuring between 21-24 cm in length and weighing around 70-90 grams. It has a distinctive black and white plumage, with a white forehead, cheeks, and belly, and a black cap, back, and wings. The species is known for its unique behavior of storing acorns in holes it creates in trees, which it uses as a food source during the winter months.

These woodpeckers are highly social and often live in family groups, where they cooperate in the storage and defense of their acorn caches. They are also known for their complex vocalizations, which include a variety of calls and drumming sounds used for communication and territorial display.

Acorn Woodpeckers play an important role in their ecosystems, serving as both seed dispersers and predators of insects and other small invertebrates. They are found in a variety of habitats, including oak and pine-oak woodlands, and are considered to be an indicator species of the overall health of these ecosystems.
